stem: The nurse is preparing to administer morning medications to four clients with diabetes. Based on the documentation in the Diabetes Meal & Med Log, match each type of insulin to the correct time the nurse should prepare to assess for hypoglycemia.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:30: Morning rounds. 4 clients scheduled for various insulin types. Breakfast trays arriving at 08:00. 
Client 1: Scheduled for Insulin Aspart. 
Client 2: Scheduled for Insulin Regular. 
Client 3: Scheduled for Insulin NPH. 
Client 4: Scheduled for Insulin Glargine.

tabs.title: BGM Log
tabs.content: Awaiting post-prandial results. All morning pre-prandial results were between 140–180 mg/dL.

rationale.correct: Rapid-acting insulin (r1) like Aspart peaks quickly, requiring a food tray at the bedside immediately (c1). Short-acting Regular (r2) peaks in 2-5 hours (c2). Intermediate NPH (r3) peaks mid-afternoon (4-12 hours) (c3), and Glargine (r4) has no peak (c4). Hypoglycemia risk is highest during these peaks.
clinicalPearls: Rapid: '15 mins feels like an hour during 3 rapid years' (15 min onset, 1 hr peak, 3 hr duration).
Regular: 'Short-staffed nurses go from 30 patients to 2, then 8' (30 min onset, 2-4 hr peak, 8 hr duration).
Glargine is the only one that CANNOT be mixed.

questionTrap.trap: Believing that NPH will cover the morning breakfast spike.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: NPH takes 1.5-4 hours to এমনকি START working. It is for basal/afternoon coverage, not meal-time bolus.

mnemonic.title: Insulin Race
mnemonic.expansion: Rapid = Racecar (1h). Regular = Rickshaw (4h). NPH = Night-train (12h).
